comments.commentBody:
I didn't buy Facebook stock.
I relied on the sage advice of the Winklevoss twins, who told me, "Don't trust Mark Zuckerberg."
Republicans? really? As much as disagree with most of their position on everything. The FB debacle has more to do with people's narcissism than ridiculous right wing politics.
You didn't mention Rep. Barney Frank and Sen. Chris Dodd -- two of the architects of the housing bubble.

Own the bubble, Ross. It wasn't merely that housing prices were no longer tethered to normal economic trends; it was that Republicans unleashed the monstrous greed of the financial industry, sold mortgages to people who couldn't afford them, and then packaged and sold the worthless paper which caused economic collapse. It was Republicans who were no longer tethered to fiscal reality.

I don't see much connection to Facebook, although I (shudder) sort of agree that it's an economically vacuous operation, spawned in a fit of pique by a resentful computer nerd who has truly gotten his revenge. It presents itself a social network, which is true if you define "social" as engaging in a cluster of decidedly antisocial acts involving staring at a computer screen for hours, posting vain little snippets of pointless information about yourself, and making thousands of "friends" without being aware of the irony. It has the business ethics of those TV commercials that sell junk to the gullible. Facebook presents itself as a fun way to keep track of birthdays, post photos, and blither about your personal life, but all the while it's tracking your every click, and selling your online soul to companies that will follow and harass you forever.

I thought Republicans would love that sort of thing. Live and learn.

Think of advertising as a pie. The pie hasn't really grown in 10 years, but the number of sectors trying to get a piece has multiplied. Facebook, Google, Yahoo, Twitter ... all chasing the same ad $$ as this newspaper; cable, broadcast, premium TV; magazines; radio; and on.

Ross Williams sums it up. For networking (family, interests, affinity groups etc) Facebook is great and worth every penny it doesn't cost the user. The time wasting aspect is completely in the click of the beholder as it should be. The advertising value is probably in the same order as the old 'throw away' neighborhood papers as I suspect only 1% of the content ever goes viral let alone beyond the boundaries of the connected groups.  Even when content does go viral it's doubtful advertisers get much of kick unless they've managed to create the virus in the first place as some of the smart global brands are trying to do. Check out WorldSkills Foundation for example!
Diana,  There may be a reason why you elect to pay for security protection, but for the average user Microsoft's Security Essentials or Free AVG are quite satisfactory.  Just sayin'
I think it's fairly obvious he meant "virtual," not digital.

Ross, have you heard of Google? A company that, despite your belief to the contrary, works quite well as an "ongoing operating business" - with revenue last year, if I recall correctly, of about $38 billion.

It's joined by an enormous array of other very profitable companies based on the Internet, including others primarily dependent on advertising revenue. You might even include the New York Times as one of those companies, now that its digital business and digital ad revenue has come to dominate its balance sheet.

If you've never used it, it's unlikely you have much of an idea of what Facebook facilitates. My guess is Ross doesn't use it much either. It's not a textbook or a hushed library, but it also has its uses. It's more useful and enjoyable for some than others, as is anything, but I can't say I'm much impressed by those who sneer at the folly of the masses and avoid Facebook primarily because it is popular... without even expending the effort to evaluate it for themselves.

Thank you Michael.
I was glued to NASA TV for at least 6 hours starting early in the morning around 5AM watching in amazement as Dragon came closer to the ISS. All those engineers at NASA and Space X are employees. If you go to the Space X website one will see just how many jobs are posted on their "career" site. Yes, Made in America indeed. Who else in the world has done what I saw Friday morning among other amazing space endeavors?

USA needs to keep on the math and science bandwagon and educate our younger generation. I am able to walk (thankfully) down to Smith College for graduation which I do each year for inspiration and was in awe of all 60o plus young women graduating. Check out the new Ford Engineering Building finished last year.

Back to Dragon......I posted Dragon's to all my space crazy friends on Facebook as Dragon hooked up with the ISS. Jobs, technology and Facebook all together in a morning. Fantastic!
I like them all. Thumb Up.

"Biggest flop of the decade"? Before you jump on that bandwagon, I suggest you read your colleague Joe Nocera's column for some perspective on this. Meanwhile, I think you are looking at technology much too narrowly, confining it largely to social media. Technology and globalization continue to be disruptive forces and part of the fallout of this structural change is going to be a spate of unemployment for those who lack the skills to adjust. The article below in the Atlantic is a good example. We are still the #1 manufacturing, in spite of what one hears, but there are fewer people jobs because factories are becoming more mechanized and those who work there have to know how to use computer systems. And Space X, a private sector company, just successfully launched a rocket that docked at the Space Station. These are just a couple of examples outside of social media.

http://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/2012/01/making-it-in-america...

Maybe Facebook is a fad and will be gone soon now that the vampires have sucked whatever blood they could out of it. I still think that if they opened the trading up to the users who actually made it big, it would be very successful. People would not only enjoy it but be vested in it, and support fee-based applications, games, or new ideas. But the problem is the vampires. When they smell blood, they suck.
Bruce, We've been raised to think that suckers are guys with $10 in their pocket confronted by a carny pitch man. Suckers with 10 Billion to spend are still suckers, but the pitch men wear suits.

I'm still in amazement that investors clamored to purchase Facebook stock last Friday. On the preceding Thursday, my high school economics class and I discussed whether or not the company would be worth the cost. Between the low potential for high dividends and even less for capital gains, my class arrived at the consensus that Facebook should be passed over for better opportunities. On Monday and Tuesday, we continued to track the plummeting stock to no surprise whatsoever. Ultimately, the question I derived from this experience is that if my 11th graders believed that Facebook was a poor investment, then why were so many Wall Street brokers swooning to buy it the second it went on sale?
The people who work there can't cash in their stock yet.  We will see if they're happy In 86 days.

The IPO was not a failure for Facebook - even at $30 per share the company is valued at $70 billion. Not bad for a company with 3,500 employees. The people who work there don't think it was a failure. Long term investors are betting they will figure out a way to monetize their database - not a big stretch

The Internet may indeed not be a commercial success. And the deliberate, intentional social networks like Facebook may not yield profits.

But if the only thing the internet were making available is the growing number of free online educational courses and tools from some of the best institutions of higher learning in the world, like Mr. Douthat's own alma mater, Harvard, and MIT, it will pay for itself many times over in the creation of that most amazing asset, human potential.

And to think, Mr. Douthat, that the internet was brought to us by government subsidy. Not Wall Street, not private equity.

Hold that thought, Ross.

It's a mediocre product that promotes people to write drivel about themselves and use algorithms to find out what we are interested in buying. Whether its better or worse than Microsoft or Google, I could care less.

One of the most ridiculous opinion pieces I have read in a while! Facebook raised $16 billion to fund the growth of their business. How is that a failure? The first day speculators lost money but so what? IPO buyers don't have any right to a quick profit.

Companies making purely digital products have trouble making money? Tell that to Microsoft ($23 bn profit), Google ($11 bn profit) and Oracle ($10 bn profit). Oil companies are more profitable, but they have to spend many billions before the oil begins to flow.

Facebook's P/E of 82 is not too different from the P/E Microsoft enjoyed during its rapid growth phase. Am I a buyer of Facebook stock? No, because I don't think that Facebook is as essential to the tech world as Google or Microsoft is. However, what are the alternatives for investors?

Right now you can loan your money to the US government for 10 years at the lucrative rate of 1.74%. Inflation is currently 2.3%, so basically you are guaranteed to lose value even if the US government doesn't default. Even at its current price, Facebook is a better deal IMO.
Some would say a company that enables millions of people to more easily connect and share with those that are important to them has performed a valuable service.

Thank you for coming out against Facebook and Zuckerberg idolatry. Facebook is second only to Zynga in its uselessness. I am waiting for the day that a company has a large (and successful) IPO based on selling a product or service that is good for people and society rather than on advertising revenue and a non-product.
Surely that is a matter of negotiations between the states and Amazon. New York State costumers pay sales tax when purchasing items from Amazon.
Amazon's core competency is facilitating avoidance of sales taxes by its customers.

Honestly, this is something you (the author) do not suspect the power of.
It is not about their current links, etc.. It is about the big data, of such a personal scale. It is about the tracking that is allowed in the USA and the international role of politics. If you had a powerful position, what would you pay to defend it? Twitter and Facebook can play a role in taking down whole governments, let alone build a small business.
FB has won a war of attrition, and the tracking metrics and inherent power in these metrics are quite powerful. They announce to unsuspecting people that their daughter is pregnant, to sight a recent, if tiny, globally insignificant example. Information is a kind of power. These tools are social experiments with profound effects, and thus "value", and it is unseen what can or will happen in the future.
For now, I suggest you install ghostery or similar and learn just how much of your existence is being plotted, mapped, recorded and worse.

As has been pointed out elsewhere in this paper, Facebook's IPO was a disaster only for the well-connected banking clients who got the initial shares. Normally in a big IPO that's free money, as the shares shoot up and quickly get flipped for a big profit. But the company loses out; if it had offered the shares at closer to the consensus market value, it would have raised more capital. Facebook's shares being initially sold a little too high worked out just fine for Facebook: it got more money at the expense of the banking clients who are the usual winners in an IPO. It's a loss for them, not Facebook.

Only tangential to your main point, but still.

Overall I agree with Douthat (for a change) that a lot of the potential for money making on internet information per-se is overhyped.  In the end, the best sources of information and analysis will be the ones who can charge for it, and not just give it out for free. The NY Times, Wall Street Journal, Financial Times, Economist are examples. They will have to survive by being a lot better than most everyone else, such that customers are willing to pay for their products. The notion that everything is for free on the internet is damaging to the quality and the experience.

The Masters of the Universe did just fine, Morgan Stanley made a bundle on the deal. It even benefited from the price drop.  The media declared the IPO a disaster because it contradicted its narrative. They got the story wrong and someone else must be to blame.

Go back and read Joe Nocera's excellent column about Facebook to understand why its IPO was declared a disaster. It's largely because the peeved Masters of the Universe who were unable to skim off the profits from the IPO, effortlessly. Instead, the profits went to Facebook itself. Very interesting.
But I almost agree with you that the level of sharing in Facebook cannot be healthy. I guess my age is showing--I'm not going to tell anyone what type of tea I had with breakfast, nor do I want to read about their coffee. I joined just for access to another site, and have only posted my favorite cookie recipe. That, I don't mind sharing.

Scottish fans at that World Cup provided what is still, in my opinion, one of the funniest signs I've ever seen at a soccer game. They were playing the Soviets in Malaga(it ended a 2-2 draw). Big banner, hanging over the top of the La Rosaleda stadium facing in entering crowd: "USSR-Scotland: Communism versus Alcoholism".

John, I've got to tell you, that between Malaga (where I was in a tiny town called Arroyo de la Miel, or 'Honey Brook') and Sevilla, it was quite the rollicking mix with the Scots, the Kiwis and the Brazilians, mixed in with about 200 dour, humorless KGB agents, and no Russian civilians in sight anywhere. The Scots can party with anybody, but so can the Kiwis and the Brazilians. Back then, you could buy a beer for a quarter and a bottle of something strong for about $3/liter. So yeah, the Scots left with their livers shellshocked. For Scotland, it was disappointing, but a major improvement over the embarrassment of '78.
"Communism vs. alcoholism" The funny thing is, Scotland could be labeled both. So for that matter could the USSR.

Bradley's goal reminds me of this one on a night long ago in Seville...
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AH86CmJqV9c

While I'm pleased by the outcome, as has been written before, the team the Scots put on the Pitch tonight, is and was not the SCOTLAND, of old. The SCOTLAND of Law, MacGregor, and the rest, of the iconic brave lads! Any American who got giddy over the final score tonight, doesn't know the game, or the history of the team they were facing.

Jimmy Carter really got mad at two young men grabbing some pastries?  I knew he was anal about small things, but pastries?!!   Although, he did send a few airborne rescuers in a long ago hostage situation, too few.  Or maybe too many, if he couldn't do it right.

Yes President Carter served the U. S. Navy, including duty on nuclear submarines, for 10 years and was in the reserves until 1961. Yet Mitt Romney, a draft dodger during Viet Nam, has no reservations about casting aspersions on President Carter's character and courage.

The Secret Service includes not just the travel team who accompany the president, but uniformed officers who patrol the White House each day and night.
My cousin was such an officer during the Carter administration. He and his pal had to work the overnight shift on the eve of a formal dinner for the French president.
Bored and hungry, they started eating the pastries which they found in the White House kitchen. Unfortunately, Jimmy Carter was a light sleeper. He caught the two and transfered them to a new duty station: West Virginia (sort of like being exiled to Siberia by the Soviets).
I don't think it stops at 60!  Now who's naive, SR? They just look more foolish.
Now that they have Viagra, even the over 60s they think they need it to be more "manly" to attract young women.

This can simply be distilled to a toxic combination of drugs: Testosterone and Alcohol. Most men between the ages  of 12 and 60 are susceptible. Hubristic, muscle types- especially so. In that environment, a genuine leader would have made matters clear, well in advance. In my opinion, he should be terminated.

Sullivan is out of touch with reality.He has to go,period.As Dowd mentioned, a drinking party was held the night before JFK was killed.Is that why Clint Hill has such a guilt complex?Is that why the SS limo driver failed to accelerate after the first Oswald shot?Will the REAL TRUTH ever come out?Doubt it.And the SS continues it's archaic behavior.After all,their primary job is protecting the President.Good grief!!!
